context_of_use: Users access the IFA system via supported desktop and mobile devices in order to perform their respective responsibilities from various locations.
stakeholders_and_interests: team manager: Wants to access the system from a desktop to reduce mistakes when managing team assets.
fan: Wants to access the system from a mobile phone to use the system wherever they are.
match official: Wants to access the system from a mobile phone to use it on the field or while traveling to the game.
ifa: Wants IFA employees to access the system from a desktop to more easily enter new data into the system.
ifa: Wants to bring different existing systems together so that data does not need to be stored redundantly.
ifa: Wants to support multiple languages within the system to service leagues in different countries.
ifa: Wants the system to remain reliable for at least 50,000 concurrent users so that user experience remains satisfactory.
description: This use case describes how authorized users access the IFA system from desktop and mobile devices while the system maintains reliability, multilingual support, and integration with existing systems to avoid redundant data.
triggering_event: A team manager, fan, match official, or IFA employee initiates access to the system from a desktop or mobile device.
preconditions: The IFA system is operational and reachable over the network.
The user has a compatible desktop or mobile device with network connectivity.
The user possesses valid access credentials registered in the IFA system.
The authentication service is available to verify user credentials.
Relevant user roles and associated access privileges have been configured in the system.
Languages supported by the system have been configured by the IFA.
Integration between the IFA system and existing systems has been configured to prevent redundant data storage.
postconditions: The user is successfully authenticated and has an active session in the IFA system.
The user interface is presented with functionality and tools restricted to the user’s assigned role and privileges.
The user interface is presented in the selected or default supported language.
The user’s access occurs without violating the system reliability requirement of supporting at least 50,000 concurrent users.
Data accessed by the user is obtained from integrated existing systems in a manner that avoids redundant data storage where such integrations are configured.
assumptions: User authentication is required before granting access to any non-public functionality in the IFA system.
User roles and associated access privileges are defined and maintained by the IFA within the system prior to access.
Device-specific capabilities (such as browsers or mobile apps) are compatible with the IFA system’s user interface.
Multilingual user interface text is preconfigured in the system for all supported languages.
Users are allowed to select a preferred language during access or are assigned a default language based on configuration.
The reliability requirement of at least 50,000 concurrent users is handled by the system’s underlying infrastructure and is not directly controlled by the actors in this use case.
Integration with different existing systems is already implemented and configured so that end users experience unified access without manually handling multiple systems.
User role-based restriction to relevant tools is enforced by the system based on predefined mappings between roles and available features.
Both desktop access and mobile access use the same logical authentication mechanism and authorization rules.
IFA employees referenced in the requirements are represented in this use case by the actor label "ifa".
requirements_met: The system shall allow team managers to access the system from desktop devices to support accurate management of team assets.
The system shall allow fans to access the system from mobile phones so that they can use the system wherever they are.
The system shall allow match officials to access the system from mobile phones so that they can use the system on the field or while traveling to games.
The system shall allow IFA employees to access the system from desktop devices to facilitate efficient data entry.
The system shall support user access via both desktop and mobile platforms under a unified access mechanism.
The system shall restrict user access to only the tools and functions relevant to the user’s role in order to reduce confusion.
The system shall support multiple languages in the user interface so that users from different countries can be serviced.
The system shall maintain reliable operation for at least 50,000 concurrent users while users access the system.
The system shall integrate with existing systems in a way that avoids redundant data storage from the perspective of users accessing data.
The system shall apply role-based access control so that only authorized users can access protected system functionality.
outstanding_issues: The specific authentication mechanism (for example, password-based login, single sign-on, or multi-factor authentication) has not been defined.
The list of supported languages and the default language selection policy have not been specified.
The set of desktop platforms and mobile platforms that must be officially supported has not been defined.
The precise performance criteria associated with supporting 50,000 concurrent users, such as maximum response time thresholds, have not been detailed.
The detailed mapping between user roles (team manager, fan, match official, IFA employee) and the specific tools and functions available after access remains to be specified.
The nature and boundaries of integration with existing systems, including which systems are integrated and what data is shared, have not been fully described.
main_flow: 1. User (team manager, fan, match official, or ifa) initiates access to the IFA system from a desktop browser or mobile application → System establishes a network connection endpoint and presents an access interface for credential entry or session initiation.

2. User enters required access credentials and, if available, selects a preferred language for the session → System submits the provided credentials to the authentication service and captures the language preference.

3. Authentication service validates the user credentials and returns an authentication decision → System receives the decision and, on successful validation, establishes an authenticated user session.

4. System determines the user’s role and associated access privileges based on stored configuration → System constructs a role-specific main interface that exposes only tools and functions relevant to the user’s role.
5. System applies the selected or default language to all user interface elements for the session → System renders the localized user interface for the desktop or mobile device in use.

6. System retrieves any required user-specific or role-specific data from integrated existing systems where configured → System presents unified, non-redundant data to the user within the role-specific interface.

7. User begins interacting with the system using the provided role-specific interface on the desktop or mobile device → System maintains the active session while upholding the reliability constraint of supporting at least 50,000 concurrent users.
alternative_flows: AF-1 (from Step 2): User does not explicitly select a preferred language during access. Condition: The language selection option is available but the user leaves it unchanged. The system applies the default language configured for the user or, if no user-specific default exists, the system-wide default language, then continues with Step 3.

AF-2 (from Step 1): User accesses the IFA system from a different type of mobile device or desktop environment than originally targeted. Condition: The device still meets minimum compatibility requirements. The system adapts the presentation layer to the detected device form factor while keeping authentication and authorization behavior unchanged, and then proceeds with Step 2.
exception_flows: EF-1 (from Step 1): Network connection to the IFA system cannot be established. The system is unreachable or the connection attempt times out. The system does not present the access interface and may return a generic connectivity error message to the user via the client device. The use case ends without establishing a session.

EF-2 (from Step 3): Authentication service rejects the user credentials as invalid. The system notifies the user that authentication has failed and offers the user the option to re-enter credentials. If the user chooses to retry, the flow returns to Step 2; otherwise, the use case ends without granting access.

EF-3 (from Step 3): Authentication service is unavailable or returns an error. The system informs the user that access cannot be completed due to an authentication service issue and does not establish a session. The use case ends without granting access.

EF-4 (from Step 4): The system cannot determine a valid role or associated access privileges for the authenticated user. The system informs the user that their account is not properly configured for access and terminates the session. The use case ends without presenting the main interface.

EF-5 (from Step 6): Retrieval of data from integrated existing systems fails due to integration errors or unavailability. The system informs the user that some data may be temporarily unavailable, omits the unavailable integrated data from the interface, logs the incident, and continues the session using only data that is currently available.
information_for_steps: 1. Device type, network endpoint, client application identifier.
2. User identifier, authentication credentials, optional language preference.
3. Authentication result, authentication token, session identifier.
4. User role, role-to-privilege mappings, list of authorized tools and functions.
5. Selected language code, localized user interface resources.
6. References to integrated systems, user-specific and role-specific data retrieved from integrated systems, consolidated data view.
7. Session activity data, concurrent session counters, reliability monitoring metrics.
